Introduction

Source: vignettes/introduction.Rmd
introduction.Rmd

Introduction

Efficient experimental designs have become very popular in stated preference research since their introduction in the mid 00s (Scarpa and Rose 2008).

Existing software

Several software packages exist, for example, SAS (Kuhfeld 2007) or NGENE (Rose et al. 2018), that can create a wide range of experimental designs ranging from full factorial to orthogonal to efficient designs. However, many of them are expensive and the code base is closed source and proprietary. In our view, this creates an unnecessary barrier for researchers that may not have access to institutional licenses or the funding necessary to buy an individual license, and it makes it more difficult for other researchers to use and build on existing research code.

Existing R packages

A plethora of R packages already exist to create a wide range of different experimental designs (see the CRAN Task View), however, none of them are directly aimed at creating efficient stated preference experimental designs. For example, the AlgDesign package can create full factorial and a type of D-optimal design and the OptimalDesign package calculates unblocked D-, A- and I- optimal designs.

Why another package?

spdesign has an easy-to-use interface that people familiar with R will find intuitive to use. Users who have previously used NGENE will find the syntax somewhat familiar.

The package interfaces nicely with the shinySP package (under development), which allow users to easily self-host stated preference experiments using Shiny, and shares some functions with the cmdlR package.

The package leverages the power of R’s powerful expression parsers to enable users familiar with R to use basic mathematical operators when defining utility functions and specifying attribute levels and parameter priors. The code is fully open source and freely available to anyone under a permissive MIT license. We have done our best to document the code, its functions and workflow to allow anyone to extend and contribute to the project. If you wish to do so, please read the guidelines for how to contribute and the detailed package documentation. All contributions are acknowledged and tracked using the functionalities available through GitHub.

Acknowledgements

The authors are grateful to members of the Applied Choice Research Group (ACRG) at the University of Stirling for extensively testing the package and providing feedback on the UI prior to the release of v0.1.0.

References

Kuhfeld, Warren F. 2007. “Marketing Research Methods in SAS: Experimental Design, Choice, Conjoint, and Graphical Techniques.” In SAS Document TS-694. http://support.sas.com/techsup/technote/ts694.pdf.

Rose, John M., Andrew T. Collins, Michiel Bliemer, and David A. Hensher. 2018. NGENE (version 1.2.1). Choice Metrics. http://choice-metrics.com/.

Scarpa, Riccardo, and John M. Rose. 2008. “Design Efficiency for Non-Market Valuation with Choice Modelling: How to Measure It, What to Report and Why*.” Australian Journal of Agricultural and Resource Economics 52 (3): 253–82. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-8489.2007.00436.x.
